awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating Magmatic Differentiation in a Fossil Upper-Crustal Silicic Magma System: Stillwater Range, NV
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanic eruptions involving high-silica rhyolite magmas are explosive, violent, and have high hazard potential. Yet, there remain significant debates as to how these magmas are generated and when and why they erupt. Understanding the processes and timescales related to these questions is key to developing effective volcanic hazard programs and requires an understanding of how the physical and thermal conditions of a magmatic system change over timescales ranging from days to millions of years. Efforts focused on monitoring and imaging the subsurface at active volcanoes can provide some of this information, but they cannot inform on processes that occur on very long timescales (thousands to million years). Consequently, research on systems where both erupted and non-erupted portions of the magmatic system are preserved can be used to better understand the entire history of a volcanic system. The goal of this project is to study a ‘fossil’ magmatic system – the IXL pluton (Nevada) –in an effort to constrain the processes that lead to the generation, and possible eruption, of high-silica rhyolite magma. Funding will support two graduate and three undergraduate students from Purdue University, Stanford University, and the University of Nevada-Reno. An additional important outcome of this work will be the production of a student-led documentary that will highlight the research, with an emphasis on women conducting field-based scientific research. This will be done through collaboration with the Science Communication Hitchcock Project within the Reynolds School of Journalism at the University of Nevada-Reno and will result in the dissemination of this research to the general public in an engaging fashion.

Most of the proposed mechanisms for production of high-silica rhyolite involve its separation from a crystal-rich magma reservoir through gravitationally driven processes like crystal settling and compaction. Importantly, both processes should produce vertical geochemical and textural gradients in magma reservoirs. The Miocene IXL pluton offers an ideal location to document these gradients because it is well exposed in a coherent crustal section with a known paleo-vertical orientation. To assess whether these gradients are present, the PIs will utilize high-density geochemical measurements coupled with electron back scattered diffraction (EBSD) textural studies and constrain the timescales over which they occurred using high-precision U-Pb zircon geochronology. Additionally, U-Pb zircon geochronology, diffusion chronometry, and geochemical studies will be used to determine whether any of the overlying volcanic rocks are related to the pluton and to assess the magmatic processes that led to their eruption. The combination of these techniques will provide a holistic view of silicic magma evolution in the upper crust and can be used to better interpret the geophysical data that is used to assess volcanic hazards at modern volcanoes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Explosive eruptions from volcanoes pose tremendous hazards to humans and infrastructure. Assessing the hazards posed by such volcanoes requires knowledge of how magma is stored beneath them. This project addressed this question by studying an ancient volcano in central Nevada. Faulting at this location has tilted the ancient volcano on its side and erosion has exposed rocks that crystallized from magma underneath the volcano, as well as rocks that solidified on the Earth’s surface following their eruption from the volcano. The paired intrusive and extrusive record of magmatism allowed the principal investigators to reconstruct the history of magmatic activity at this location using high-precision isotopic measurements to determine the age of different eruptive and intrusive events. Surprisingly, there is no preserved eruptive material that matches the age of intrusive activity. Instead, the system seems to have rapidly transitioned from primarily erupting magmas to the Earth’s surface to primarily intruding magmas beneath the volcanic edifice. The apparent decoupling of intrusive and extrusive magmatism at this ancient volcano has implications for how we should assess hazards at active volcanoes, since large volumes of magma may accumulate under a volcanic edifice that appears dormant.

This project supported principal investigator Michael Eddy as an early career researcher, as well as a female PhD student and a female postdoctoral researcher. A component of the broader impacts of this project was collaborating with the University of Nevada Reynolds School of Journalism to produce a short film that highlights the role of female geoscientists in field research. The film can be seen on Youtube under the title “Empowering Voices in Science: A Collaborative Film Project Showcasing Female Scientists in Fieldwork”. The goal of the film was to inspire other young women to pursue field-based scientific research and to provide experience in science journalism to the students at the University of Nevada Reynolds School of Journalism.
